conclusion: To decide whether more heat is taken in or given out during one complete cycle we only have to identify the net direction of the energy exchange.
For any closed cycle of an ideal gas, net heat absorbed in the cycle equals net work done by the gas in the cycle.
If the curve on the p-V diagram is traversed counter-clockwise, the gas does negative work (work is done on the gas) and net heat is rejected.
If it is traversed clockwise, the gas does positive work and net heat is absorbed.
In the figure the path is a → b (isochoric, ↑P), b → c (adiabatic, ↑V, ↓P), c → d (isochoric, ↓P), d → a (adiabatic, ↓V, ↑P).

premise: The sequence a → b → c → d → a encloses the cycle in a counter-clockwise sense.
conclusion: Consequently, the algebraic work done by the gas is negative.
Net heat added to the gas < 0

premise: Net heat added to the gas < 0
conclusion: The magnitude of heat released is greater than the magnitude of heat absorbed.

premise: The magnitude of heat released is greater than the magnitude of heat absorbed.
conclusion: During one complete cycle the gas rejects more heat than it absorbs.
